{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2986830,"name":"Will Rueter","username":"wrueter","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/db5fbb/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-08T23:32:13.522Z","cooked":"

What is the feasibility of converting a close-range, lob shooter for Rapid React into a long-range shooter that is accurate from anywhere using the velocity of our robot (swerve chassis, assume fairly accurate velo) to power the horizontal translation? I would assume since it is just projectile motion, this should work fairly well since it’s fairly basic physics. Also would appreciate any lob shooter designs that might work with this. Not planning to design our shooter around this, just think it’s a fun idea that might have a small payoff later in the season if our shooter design prohibits just using a sliding plate to change trajectory of the cargo.

I don’t think that’d work very well for several reasons:

  • Your robot would probably need to move rather fast to gain an advantage, possibly top speed or more
  • Defense against a robot that relies on its speed in order to shoot would be as simple as repeatedly bumping into it to prevent it from speeding up
  • The window to shoot in is pretty narrow (probably about 4 feet for the Rapid React goal, which is 0.5 seconds if the robot is traveling at 8fps)
","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2022-01-09T00:33:10.183Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":321,"readers_count":320,"score":114.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":399089,"topic_slug":"converting-close-lob-shooter-to-long-range-with-no-mechanical-change","display_username":"Mark Ghebrial","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48253,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Alumnus of Team 3309, the Friarbots"},"post_url":"/t/converting-close-lob-shooter-to-long-range-with-no-mechanical-change/399089/2","custom_user_title":"Alumnus of Team 3309, the Friarbots","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2987026,"name":"","username":"E.Li","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/df705f/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-09T04:36:24.493Z","cooked":"

Especially considering the fewer restrictions on defense this year, having the shooting dependent on the velocity of the robot is risky. “Let them shoot” only applies to when the robot is touching the launch pad, aka shooting while still. Opponent robots can easily come in your way and pin you or get in the way of the shot. Also, consider the fact that the robot won’t always be traveling at a constant velocity. While feasible to consider during calculations in the code, it’s not worth the hassle compared to sticking to more popular shooting designs. Would be cool if you got this to work though.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2022-01-09T04:36:24.493Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":89.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":399089,"topic_slug":"converting-close-lob-shooter-to-long-range-with-no-mechanical-change","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/converting-close-lob-shooter-to-long-range-with-no-mechanical-change/399089/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2988505,"name":"Will Rueter","username":"wrueter","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/db5fbb/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-10T20:54:32.580Z","cooked":"
  • Our current chassis has a top speed of about 15 fps, plenty fast to make a difference. I’ll do the math later to check.
  • Of course, I’m not suggesting we build a robot around this concept. This is more just to have an extra trick up our sleeve, say in the playoffs when other teams think we are solely close range, or late game if we don’t have time to drive up for a close shot but we could pop off a long shot and go climb.
  • Not sure what you mean. Accuracy should be accounted for with vision and Odometry, both of which should be accurate this year, if that’s what you mean.
